Sentence: And this is the question I shall attempt to answer.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: The Hindus have received their religion through revelation, the Vedas.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: They hold that the Vedas are without beginning and without end.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: It may sound ludicrous to this audience, how a book can be without beginning or end.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: But by the Vedas no books are meant.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: They mean the accumulated treasury of spiritual laws discovered by different persons in different times.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Just as the law of gravitation existed before its discovery, and would exist if all humanity forgot it, so is it with the laws that govern the spiritual world.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: The moral, ethical, and spiritual relations between soul and soul and between individual spirits and the Father of all spirits, were there before their discovery, and would remain even if we forgot them.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: The discoverers of these laws are called Rishis, and we honour them as perfected beings.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: I am glad to tell this audience that some of the very greatest of them were women.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Here it may be said that these laws as laws may be without end, but they must have had a beginning.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: The Vedas teach us that creation is without beginning or end.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Science is said to have proved that the sum total of cosmic energy is always the same.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Then, if there was a time when nothing existed, where was all this manifested energy.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Some say it was in a potential form in God.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: In that case God is sometimes potential and sometimes kinetic, which would make Him mutable.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Everything mutable is a compound, and everything compound must undergo that change which is called destruction.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: So God would die, which is absurd.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Therefore there never was a time when there was no creation.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: If I may be allowed to use a simile, creation and creator are two lines, without beginning and without end, running parallel to each other.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: God is the ever active providence, by whose power systems after systems are being evolved out of chaos, made to run for a time and again destroyed.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: This is what the Brâhmin boy repeats every day: “The sun and the moon, the Lord created like the suns and moons of previous cycles.” And this agrees with modern science.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Here I stand and if I shut my eyes, and try to conceive my existence, “I”, “I”, “I”, what is the idea before me.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: The idea of a body.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Am I, then, nothing but a combination of material substances.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: The Vedas declare, “No”.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: I am a spirit living in a body.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: I am not the body.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: The body will die, but I shall not die.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Here am I in this body; it will fall, but I shall go on living.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: I had also a past.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: The soul was not created, for creation means a combination which means a certain future dissolution.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: If then the soul was created, it must die.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Some are born happy, enjoy perfect health, with beautiful body, mental vigour and all wants supplied.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Others are born miserable, some are without hands or feet, others again are idiots and only drag on a wretched existence.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Why, if they are all created, why does a just and merciful God create one happy and another unhappy, why is He so partial.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Nor would it mend matters in the least to hold that those who are miserable in this life will be happy in a future one.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Why should a man be miserable even here in the reign of a just and merciful God.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: In the second place, the idea of a creator God does not explain the anomaly, but simply expresses the cruel fiat of an all-powerful being.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: There must have been causes, then, before his birth, to make a man miserable or happy and those were his past actions.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Are not all the tendencies of the mind and the body accounted for by inherited aptitude.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: Here are two parallel lines of existence — one of the mind, the other of matter.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: If matter and its transformations answer for all that we have, there is no necessity for supposing the existence of a soul.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: But it cannot be proved that thought has been evolved out of matter, and if a philosophical monism is inevitable, spiritual monism is certainly logical and no less desirable than a materialistic monism; but neither of these is necessary here.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: We cannot deny that bodies acquire certain tendencies from heredity, but those tendencies only mean the physical configuration, through which a peculiar mind alone can act in a peculiar way.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: There are other tendencies peculiar to a soul caused by its past actions.

Title: Paper on Hinduism
Sentence: And a soul with a certain tendency would by the laws of affinity take birth in a body which is the fittest instrument for the display of that tendency.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Madame Speaker and Deputy Speaker, President of the Senate and Deputy President, Deputy Presidents, Distinguished members of parliament, Esteemed guests, Comrades, Ladies and Gentlemen, I stand before you aware of the momentous times that we are traversing.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: These times also demand of us that we regularly account to this august assembly about the work entrusted to us by the electorate.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Much can be said about the content of the debate in the current session.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: On occasion, strong language has been used to drive home strongly-held belief.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Within the limits of what is befitting of members of this House, this shows that we have at last a robust and vibrant democracy, with broad consensus on the most important national questions.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Down the years, human society has pitted itself against the pestilences of poverty, disease and ignorance.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Progress has been achieved while reverses have also been sustained.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: It is incumbent on South Africa to be in the company of those who have recorded more success than failure.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: At the end of the day, the yardstick that we shall all be judged by is one and one only: and that is, are we, through our endeavours here, creating the basis to better the lives of all South Africans.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: This is not because the people have some subjective expectations fanned during an election campaign.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Neither is it because there is a magic wand that they see in the new government.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Millions have suffered deprivation for decades and they have the right to seek redress.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: They fought and voted for change; and change the people of South Africa must have.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: A hundred days ago, the President and Deputy Presidents of the new democratic republic were sworn in.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Our people and the whole world marvelled at what has been variously characterised as a miracle and an epoch-making event.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Are we worthy of their trust and confidence.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Our negotiation process delivered a unique transitional mechanism which accommodates major opposition parties in a Government of National Unity.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Further, we are, together, finding creative ways of utilising the talents of all other parties in the task of nation-building.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Naturally, we are all striving to find the correct balance in this new terrain.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: What is crucial, however, is that we have forged an enduring national consensus on the interim constitution and the broad objectives of reconstruction and development.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: This consensus is neither an imposition of one party over others; nor a honeymoon premised on the fickle whims of a fleeting romance.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: What brings us together is the overriding commitment to a joint national effort to reconcile our nation and improve its well-being.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: The unique product of our negotiations - the Interim Constitution and Charter of Fundamental Rights, and now the RDP - constitute the firm foundation for launching our nation from the mire of conflict, poverty, disease and ignorance.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: These agreements were reached because they were, and still are, absolutely necessary for South Africa.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: They are not about to fade away like a passing bliss.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: This does not subtract from the fact that there are different constituencies with divergent interests represented by our diverse parties.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: We should not be fearful of the obvious consequence: that there are bound to be differences of emphasis and approach on a variety of matters.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: To present a facade of unity on each and every issue would be artificial, undemocratic and patently pretentious.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: The more these issues are aired and opened up for public debate, the better for the kind of democracy we seek to build.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Handled within the bounds dictated by the interests of coherent and effective governance, such debate will definitely enrich our body politic.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: This applies equally to debate within parties about how to manage this novel experience.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: From the outset, the government of National Unity set itself two interrelated tasks: reconciliation and reconstruction, nation- building and development.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: This is South Africa's challenge today.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: It will remain our challenge for many years to come.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: A hundred days after our inauguration, our overwhelming impression of our reality is that: * our nation has succeeded to handle its problems with great wisdom; * we have a government that has brought together bitter enemies into a constructive relationship; * our parliament and cabinet have properly focused on the task of reconstruction and development; and * we have a government that is in control and whose programmes are on course.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: This is the essence of our collective success - an achievement that no sceptic can take away from our nation.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: In this regard, we should congratulate all South Africans for the reconciliatory spirit with which they have handled the transition, and for their patience, as the new government found its feet.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Yet there are problems that need urgent attention, such as violence in the East Rand and Natal, the wanton killing of security force members, abuse and kidnapping of children and various other crimes.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Among these, the traffic in narcotics and drug abuse need the most serious and urgent attention.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: I have had discussions with the ministers concerned, and these matters are being sufficiently canvassed in their budget debates.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: There can be no argument about the need to take urgent, visible and effective measures to eradicate these problems.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Questions have been asked about the slow pace in ending racism in some work-places.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Legislation exists or is being prepared to deal with these problems.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: But, legislation on its own cannot change attitudes.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: We appeal to all South Africans to ensure that discrimination, abuse and any other backward attitudes against others, based on differences of gender, race, religion, language or other distinctions are done away with.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: The issue of a Truth and Reconciliation Commission has generated much public debate and some apprehension.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: The Minister of Justice is working to achieve broad agreement on this sensitive matter.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: In a nutshell, what this issue raises is how we deal with a past that contained gross violations of human rights - a past which threatens to live with us like a festering sore.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: The question of amnesty for those who had done wrong is dealt with in the interim constitution.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: The challenge is to ensure that amnesty helps to heal the wounds of the past by also addressing the plight of the victims.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: A truth and Reconciliation Commission will therefore need to operate on the basis of certain core principles: Firstly, it will manage and supervise the process of amnesty as required by the Constitution, in accordance with the principle of disclosure and other criteria laid down by the law.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Secondly, it will make recommendations on steps to be taken to ensure that such violations never take place again; to build respect for the law; to restore the dignity of victims and their families and provide some degree of reparation.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Thirdly, such a Commission will not be a Court nor a Tribunal.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: In this respect, we agree with the view of many sectors, including the police services, that any prosecutions and trials should be for the Attorney-General and recognised Courts of Law to handle.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: Needless to say, such a Commission will have to operate in an even-handed fashion on the basis of non-partisan criteria.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: We are confident that this balanced approach, based on consultation among all our people and drawing on the positive experiences of other countries, will help resolve the matter in a manner that benefits the country as a whole.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: In reviewing the implementation of the Reconstruction and Development Programme, we should keep in mind the reality that the progress that we make in reconciling our nation will determine the pace at which this programme is implemented.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: On the other hand, reconciliation will remain shallow if it is not accompanied by thorough-going changes in all areas of life.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: The RDP should, therefore, be understood as an all-encompassing process of transforming society in its totality to ensure a better life for all.

Title: 100 Day Speech to Parliament
Sentence: It addresses both the principal goals of trans- formation and ways of managing it.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I am the First Accused.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I hold a Bachelor's Degree in Arts and practised as an attorney in Johannesburg for a number of years in partnership with Oliver Tambo.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I am a convicted prisoner serving five years for leaving the country without a permit and for inciting people to go on strike at the end of May 1961.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: At the outset, I want to say that the suggestion made by the State in its opening that the struggle in South Africa is under the influence of foreigners or communists is wholly incorrect.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I have done whatever I did, both as an individual and as a leader of my people, because of my experience in South Africa and my own proudly felt African background, and not because of what any outsider might have said.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: In my youth in the Transkei I listened to the elders of my tribe telling stories of the old days.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Amongst the tales they related to me were those of wars fought by our ancestors in defence of the fatherland.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The names of Dingane and Bambata, Hintsa and Makana, Squngthi and Dalasile, Moshoeshoe and Sekhukhuni, were praised as the glory of the entire African nation.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I hoped then that life might offer me the opportunity to serve my people and make my own humble contribution to their freedom struggle.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: This is what has motivated me in all that I have done in relation to the charges made against me in this case.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Having said this, I must deal immediately and at some length with the question of violence.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Some of the things so far told to the Court are true and some are untrue.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I do not, however, deny that I planned sabotage.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I did not plan it in a spirit of recklessness, nor because I have any love of violence.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I planned it as a result of a calm and sober assessment of the political situation that had arisen after many years of tyranny, exploitation, and oppression of my people by the Whites.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I admit immediately that I was one of the persons who helped to form Umkhonto we Sizwe, and that I played a prominent role in its affairs until I was arrested in August 1962.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: In the statement which I am about to make I shall correct certain false impressions which have been created by State witnesses.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Amongst other things, I will demonstrate that certain of the acts referred to in the evidence were not and could not have been committed by Umkhonto.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I will also deal with the relationship between the African National Congress and Umkhonto, and with the part which I personally have played in the affairs of both organizations.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I shall deal also with the part played by the Communist Party.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: In order to explain these matters properly, I will have to explain what Umkhonto set out to achieve; what methods it prescribed for the achievement of these objects, and why these methods were chosen.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I will also have to explain how I became involved in the activities of these organizations.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I deny that Umkhonto was responsible for a number of acts which clearly fell outside the policy of the organisation, and which have been charged in the indictment against us.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I do not know what justification there was for these acts, but to demonstrate that they could not have been authorized by Umkhonto, I want to refer briefly to the roots and policy of the organization.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I have already mentioned that I was one of the persons who helped to form Umkhonto.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I, and the others who started the organization, did so for two reasons.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Firstly, we believed that as a result of Government policy, violence by the African people had become inevitable, and that unless responsible leadership was given to canalize and control the feelings of our people, there would be outbreaks of terrorism which would produce an intensity of bitterness and hostility between the various races of this country which is not produced even by war.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Secondly, we felt that without violence there would be no way open to the African people to succeed in their struggle against the principle of white supremacy.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: All lawful modes of expressing opposition to this principle had been closed by legislation, and we were placed in a position in which we had either to accept a permanent state of inferiority, or to defy the Government.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: We chose to defy the law.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: We first broke the law in a way which avoided any recourse to violence; when this form was legislated against, and then the Government resorted to a show of force to crush opposition to its policies, only then did we decide to answer violence with violence.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: But the violence which we chose to adopt was not terrorism.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: We who formed Umkhonto were all members of the African National Congress, and had behind us the ANC tradition of non-violence and negotiation as a means of solving political disputes.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: We believe that South Africa belongs to all the people who live in it, and not to one group, be it black or white.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: We did not want an interracial war, and tried to avoid it to the last minute.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: If the Court is in doubt about this, it will be seen that the whole history of our organization bears out what I have said, and what I will subsequently say, when I describe the tactics which Umkhonto decided to adopt.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I want, therefore, to say something about the African National Congress.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The African National Congress was formed in 1912 to defend the rights of the African people which had been seriously curtailed by the South Africa Act, and which were then being threatened by the Native Land Act.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: For thirty-seven years - that is until 1949 - it adhered strictly to a constitutional struggle.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: It put forward demands and resolutions; it sent delegations to the Government in the belief that African grievances could be settled through peaceful discussion and that Africans could advance gradually to full political rights.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: But White Governments remained unmoved, and the rights of Africans became less instead of becoming greater.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: In the words of my leader, Chief Lutuli, who became President of the ANC in 1952, and who was later awarded the Nobel Peace Prize: "who will deny that thirty years of my life have been spent knocking in vain, patiently, moderately, and modestly at a closed and barred door.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: What have been the fruits of moderation.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The past thirty years have seen the greatest number of laws restricting our rights and progress, until today we have reached a stage where we have almost no rights at all".
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Even after 1949, the ANC remained determined to avoid violence.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: At this time, however, there was a change from the strictly constitutional means of protest which had been employed in the past.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The change was embodied in a decision which was taken to protest against apartheid legislation by peaceful, but unlawful, demonstrations against certain laws.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Pursuant to this policy the ANC launched the Defiance Campaign, in which I was placed in charge of volunteers.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: This campaign was based on the principles of passive resistance.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: More than 8,500 people defied apartheid laws and went to jail.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Yet there was not a single instance of violence in the course of this campaign on the part of any defier.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I and nineteen colleagues were convicted for the role which we played in organizing the campaign, but our sentences were suspended mainly because the Judge found that discipline and non-violence had been stressed throughout.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: This was the time when the volunteer section of the ANC was established, and when the word 'Amadelakufa' was first used: this was the time when the volunteers were asked to take a pledge to uphold certain principles.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Evidence dealing with volunteers and their pledges has been introduced into this case, but completely out of context.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The volunteers were not, and are not, the soldiers of a black army pledged to fight a civil war against the whites.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: They were, and are.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: dedicated workers who are prepared to lead campaigns initiated by the ANC to distribute leaflets, to organize strikes, or do whatever the particular campaign required.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: They are called volunteers because they volunteer to face the penalties of imprisonment and whipping which are now prescribed by the legislature for such acts.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: During the Defiance Campaign, the Public Safety Act and the Criminal Law Amendment Act were passed.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: These Statutes provided harsher penalties for offences committed by way of protests against laws.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Despite this, the protests continued and the ANC adhered to its policy of non-violence.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: In 1956, 156 leading members of the Congress Alliance, including myself, were arrested on a charge of high treason and charges under the Suppression of Communism Act.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The non-violent policy of the ANC was put in issue by the State, but when the Court gave judgement some five years later, it found that the ANC did not have a policy of violence.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: We were acquitted on all counts, which included a count that the ANC sought to set up a communist state in place of the existing regime.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The Government has always sought to label all its opponents as communists.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: This allegation has been repeated in the present case, but as I will show, the ANC is not, and never has been, a communist organization.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: In 1960 there was the shooting at Sharpeville, which resulted in the proclamation of a state of emergency and the declaration of the ANC as an unlawful organization.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: My colleagues and I, after careful consideration, decided that we would not obey this decree.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The African people were not part of the Government and did not make the laws by which they were governed.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: We believed in the words of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, that 'the will of the people shall be the basis of authority of the Government', and for us to accept the banning was equivalent to accepting the silencing of the Africans for all time.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The ANC refused to dissolve, but instead went underground.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: We believed it was our duty to preserve this organization which had been built up with almost fifty years of unremitting toil.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: I have no doubt that no self-respecting White political organization would disband itself if declared illegal by a government in which it had no say.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: In 1960 the Government held a referendum which led to the establishment of the Republic.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: Africans, who constituted approximately 70 per cent of the population of South Africa, were not entitled to vote, and were not even consulted about the proposed constitutional change.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: All of us were apprehensive of our future under the proposed White Republic, and a resolution was taken to hold an All-In African Conference to call for a National Convention, and to organize mass demonstrations on the eve of the unwanted Republic, if the Government failed to call the Convention.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: I am prepared to die
Sentence: The conference was attended by Africans of various political persuasions.
Context: Struggle against apartheid in South Africa.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We would like to thank you most sincerely for giving us the opportunity to address this forty-sixth session of the General Assembly as it discusses the question of South Africa.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We say this because we are acutely aware and deeply appreciative of the role that this Organization has played since its foundation in the struggle for the emancipation of our people from the tyranny of racial oppression.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We meet here today shortly before the political formations of our country gather together in a Convention for a Democratic South Africa, to begin the process that will lead to the adoption of a democratic constitution.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: As our country starts on its final lap towards the realization of the goals enshrined in the United Nations Charter, the Declaration on Human Rights and the Declaration on South Africa adopted by this Assembly two years ago this month, the leadership of the ANC thought that it was important that we should come back to New York to share with you our views on this subject.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Thanks to the joint efforts of our people and of the Governments and peoples represented here, South Africa has embarked on its own race to normality.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We can see rising on the horizon a new glorious entity which will no longer be spoken of as the pariah among the nations, the detestable example of what is impermissible in the ordering of human relations, the homeland of a crime against humanity.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We are beginning to see emerge a new country which, because it arrives so late at the festival of liberty, must surely value freedom like the apple of its eye and strive hardest to live up to the dream of all humanity throughout the ages for emancipation, prosperity, happiness and peace.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We envision a South Africa which will, in all respects, belong to all who live in it, black and white.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Its political life will be governed by a thoroughgoing democratic constitution, based on the principle of "one person, one vote", without any distinction on grounds of race, colour, gender or creed and without any element whatsoever of racial domination and discrimination.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This will bring to its demise the present constitution of South Africa, which this Organization categorized as null and void.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We also want to see entrenched all the necessary provisions ensuring the fullest possible protection and advancement of the fundamental human rights of every South African citizen.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: As part of this, and to ensure the rule of law, there will have to be created an independent and non-racial judiciary, as visualized in earlier documents adopted by the General Assembly.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: At the same time, the new South Africa will have to address the burning question of mass poverty, which afflicts millions of our people, especially the black population.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Also to be dealt with as a matter of urgency are, of course, questions relating to the gross racial imbalances in the distribution of income, wealth, land and opportunity.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: It is common knowledge among the majority of our people that the political settlement we seek to reach cannot survive very long if these questions relating to the standard of living of the people as a whole and the quality of life are not addressed.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: That is why the issue of the growth of the economy and its restructuring to serve the needs of the entire population has to be an integral part of the process of the reconstruction of South Africa as a democratic, peaceful and stable country.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The new South Africa will, of course, seek to normalize its relations with the rest of the world.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: In this context, we must make the point that we fully respect the position spelt out in the General Assembly consensus declaration on South Africa concerning the conditions that our country must meet in order to provide the basis for an internationally acceptable solution of the South African question and for its full integration among the community of nations.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Such integration would undoubtedly have to take full account of the fact that we are an integral part of the region of southern Africa and an integral part of the continent of Africa.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: In a world in which regional associations of various kinds have become an important part of the system of international relations, the new South Africa will seek to bring whatever it can to the process of strengthening both the region of southern Africa and our continent as a whole.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: But, of course, the reality is that we have not yet liberated our country.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: It is still ruled by a white minority regime, under an apartheid constitution.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Therefore we are faced with the continuing challenge to pursue the struggle until freedom is won.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: It has now been agreed that the "convention for a democratic South Africa", to which we have referred, should be held as of 20 December 1991.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This will mark an important step forward in the process leading to a negotiated resolution of the political problems facing our country.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: As you are undoubtedly aware, the convention will discuss such matters as the principles that will underlie the new constitution, the mechanism to draw up that constitution, an interim government that will take charge of the country until a new democratically elected government is formed, the reincorporation of the Bantustans into South Africa, the time-frames for the transitional period as a whole, and the role of the international community.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: As you can see, these are all very important matters, on which we will seek speedy decisions.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Of decisive importance to the work of the convention is the requirement that the ruling National Party should make a clear commitment that the decisions of the convention will be given legal force.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Unless that is done, the convention will be no more than a mere talking-shop.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Obviously this cannot be allowed.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: In the aftermath of the conclusion of the work of the convention, we shall need to move as quickly as possible to establish the constitution-making body.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: In our view, that should be an elected constituent assembly.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Once established, we see no reason why that assembly should not conclude its work of drawing up the new constitution within the year.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Precisely because we have not as yet reached the goal of liberation towards which all of us have striven, we believe that there is need for continued international pressure to encourage speedy movement forward towards ending the system of apartheid.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Sanctions therefore continue to be important.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: At the same time, we believe that such sanctions should be lifted in phases corresponding to actual progress being achieved within South Africa.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The two major phases ahead of us would be delineated by the establishment of the interim government, and.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: secondly, the election of the new government in terms of a democratic constitution.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We would therefore urge this assembly and its Member States to handle the issue of sanctions in this manner.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We are convinced that this is the best way to use this form of pressure to realize our common objective of securing a speedy end to the system of apartheid.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We appeal to you all to heed the voice of the oppressed on the matter, those who, after all, asked you to come to their assistance by imposing the sanctions.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: It is also critically important that the international community should support the peaceful process leading to the democratic transformation of South Africa.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We are pleased that the United Nations, as well as other international organizations, will be invited to send observers to the convention for a democratic South Africa.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This will put the peoples of the world in a better position to help determine the precise ways by which they can support the peace process in our country.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The point, however, also needs to be made that this Organization, representing the nations of the world, has always taken a firm position as an opponent of apartheid in favour of the perspective spelled out in its own Charter and in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We would therefore expect that in whatever way it participates in this political process in South Africa, it will do so as a combatant for democracy, justice and peace.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: In our quest for a democratic South Africa there have been discordant voices by some in our country, but we are confident that the people of South Africa are winning.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Whether we like it or not, the victory of the people is assured, and those who have decided to sideline themselves by not being party to this process will themselves eventually be sidelined.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We, however, as an organization are prepared to discuss with them the importance of a peaceful resolution of our problems, and we have no doubt that in taking this position, we hold views that are identical not only to those of the democratic forces in our country but also to those of democracies throughout the world.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The Assembly is also aware that in our quest to end the violence against the people, which has threatened to derail the peace process, various formations in our country, including the ANC, signed a National Peace Accord almost three months ago.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This is a very important agreement and should contribute to the establishment of a climate free of violence and therefore conducive to free political activity.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We should like to take advantage of this occasion to reiterate the call we made when we signed the Peace Accord: that the international community should take such measures as it deems fit to censure and sanction any organization in South Africa that by fomenting violence acts in a manner contrary to the purpose of the Accord.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This will greatly facilitate the process of creating a climate free of violence, as visualized in the 1989 consensus Declaration on South Africa.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The new South Africa will also need to embark on an extensive programme of socio-economic transformation.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This will be necessary both to address existing needs and to ensure the permanence of the democratic political outcome of the process of negotiations.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: It will clearly be impossible for us to carry through this programme of socio-economic changes by relying exclusively on our own resources.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We shall therefore require the support of the international community.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This support should be seen as part of the completion of the task of ending the apartheid crime against humanity by helping us to dismantle the apartheid system and liquidate its destructive consequences.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We would therefore urge this Organization to take the necessary decisions and make the relevant preparations to enable it to enter this area of activity as soon as the situation permits.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We would argue that its direct intervention will be necessary as soon as we establish the interim government to which we have referred.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) has had to intervene before, in accordance with an earlier agreement, to assist in the process of the repatriation of exiles.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We are very pleased that the UNHCR has now set itself up in the country.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We are also keenly interested in receiving help from UNHCR in resettling these returnees.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This is going to require considerable resources, especially in the light of the fact that the overwhelming majority of returnees will have to be reintegrated in urban communities.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We therefore renew our appeal both to the Organization and to its Member States to extend generous assistance to the UNHCR to enable it to carry out this very sensitive humanitarian programme.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: In this regard, we hope that the UNHCR will receive such assistance from other agencies of the United Nations as it may need to enable it to carry out its tasks properly.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Democratic South Africa will rejoin the international community in a situation in which a new world order is being born.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: As this new order will of necessity have an impact on our own destiny, we cannot avoid commenting, however briefly, on what we believe it should be.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: It is our view that this new world order should be characterized by, among other things: a democratic system of international relations; respect for the right of nations to self-determination and independence; respect for human rights; the elimination of poverty, deprivation and economic backwardness; an end to the practice of the resort to force to settle international disputes; protection of the environment; the strengthening and democratization of the institutions of this Organization to ensure that it plays its role as one of the principal architects of that new world order.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The world is becoming ever more interdependent.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: What each one of us does as an independent nation impacts on others.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We therefore have no choice but to build a system of relations which, while it guarantees such independence and seeks to exclude the possibility of one country's imposing its will on another, creates the possibility for each to have a meaningful say in how we should live together in one peaceful, stable, prosperous and free world.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: This outcome cannot allow of a situation in which the form and the content of the new world order are decided by some and have to be accepted by the rest.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: If we proceed in this manner we will continue to build conflict and instability into the world order, however much we might describe it as new.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Equally, there can be no new world order while some are super-rich and others remain abysmally poor.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Indeed, the very struggle for democracy and human rights throughout the world is made more difficult precisely by these levels of poverty.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: Clearly, what might appear an almost superhuman effort has to be made to address the issue of gross imbalances in the world economy, which have resulted in such ills as negative growth rates for many countries, an onerous debt burden and declining standards of living.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The issue of disarmament and the elimination of weapons of mass destruction remains one of the important issues of the day.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We therefore commend those countries concerned for progress that has been made in these areas and encourage them to register even more forward movement towards the final resolution of these questions.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: In this regard, we would urge the International Atomic Energy Agency to move with all speed to inspect the nuclear installations in our country to ensure full observance of the provisions of the nuclear non-proliferation Treaty.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: In the resolution of these and other questions there can be no doubt that this Organization must play a central role.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: To do so successfully it must become truly an instrument in the hands of all Member States, without any feeling that they are mere pawns.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: The reality of the matter is that there is no institution other than this Organization, and its various organs, which can provide the means by which to build an equitable and stable world order.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: To play this role it must itself enjoy the support and respect of all States throughout the world and function effectively and efficiently.

Title: Address by Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly
Sentence: We would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Mr Boutros Ghali on his election to the high post of Secretary-General of the United Nations and to wish him success in all his endeavours.

Against Apartheid

to the 641st meeting of the Special Committee
Against Apartheid
Sentence: It will for ever remain an accusation and a challenge to all men and women of conscience that it took as long as it has before all of us stood up to say enough is enough.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Long years ago we made a tryst with destiny, and now the time comes when we shall redeem our pledge, not wholly or in full measure, but very substantially.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: At the stroke of the midnight hour, when the world sleeps, India will awake to life and freedom.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: A moment comes, which comes but rarely in history, when we step out from the old to the new, when an age ends, and when the soul of a nation, long suppressed, finds utterance.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: It is fitting that at this solemn moment, we take the pledge of dedication to the service of India and her people and to the still larger cause of humanity.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: At the dawn of history, India started on her unending quest, and trackless centuries are filled with her striving and grandeur of her success and failures.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Through good and ill fortune alike, she has never lost sight of that quest, forgotten the ideals which gave her strength.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We end today a period of misfortunes and India discovers herself again.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: The achievement we celebrate today is but a step, an opening of opportunity to the greater triumphs and achievements that await us.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Are we brave enough and wise enough to grasp this opportunity and accept the challenge of the future?

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Freedom and power bring responsibility.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: The responsibility rests upon this Assembly, a sovereign body representing the sovereign people of India.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Before the birth of freedom, we have endured all the pains of labour and our hearts are heavy with the memory of this sorrrow.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Some of those pains continue even now.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Nevertheless, the past is over and it is the future that beckons us now.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: That future is not one of ease or resting but of incessant striving so that we may fulfill the pledges we have so often taken and the one we shall take today.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: The service of India means, the service of the millions who suffer.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: It means the ending of poverty and ignorance and poverty and disease and inequality of opportunity.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: The ambition of the greatest men of our generation has been to wipe every tear from every eye.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: That may be beyond us, but as long as there are tears and suffering, so long our work will not be over.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: And so we have to labour and to work, and to work hard, to give reality to our dreams.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Those dreams are for India, but they are also for the world, for all the nations and peoples are too closely knit together today for any one of them to imagine that it can live apart.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Peace is said to be indivisible, so is freedom, so is prosperity now, and also is disaster in this one world that can no longer be split into isolated fragments.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: To the people of India, whose representatives we are, we make an appeal to join us with faith and confidence in this great adventure.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: This is no time for petty and destructive criticism, no time for ill_x0002_will or blaming others.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We have to build the noble mansion of free India where all her children may dwell.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: The appointed day has come -the day appointed by destiny- and India stands forth again, after long slumber and struggle, awake, vital, free and independent.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: The past clings on to us still in some measure and we have to do much before we redeem the pledges we have so often taken.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Yet the turning-point is past, and history begins anew for us, the history which we shall live and act and others will write about.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: It is a fateful moment for us in India, for all Asia and for the world.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: A new star rises, the star of freedom in the East, a new hope comes into being, a vision long cherished materializes.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: May the star never set and that hope never be betrayed!

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We rejoice in that freedom, even though clouds surround us, and many of our people are sorrow_x0002_stricken and difficult problems encompass us.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: But freedom brings responsibilities and burdens and we have to face them in the spirit of a free and disciplined people.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: On this day our first thoughts go to the architect of this freedom, the Father of our Nation, who, embodying the old spirit of India, held aloft the torch of freedom and lighted up the darkness that surrounded us.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We have often been unworthy followers of his and have strayed from his message, but not only we but succeeding generations will remember this message and bear the imprint in their hearts of this great son of India, magnificent in his faith and strength and courage and humility.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We shall never allow that torch of freedom to be blown out, however high the wind or stormy the tempest.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Our next thoughts must be of the unknown volunteers and soldiers of freedom who, without praise or reward, have served India even unto death.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We think also of our brothers and sisters who have been cut off from us by political boundaries and who unhappily cannot share at present in the freedom that has come.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: They are of us and will remain of us whatever may happen, and we shall be sharers in their good [or] ill fortune alike.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: The future beckons to us.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: Whither do we go and what shall be our endeavour?

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: To bring freedom and opportunity to the common man, to the peasants and workers of India; to fight and end poverty and ignorance and disease; to build up a prosperous, democratic and progressive nation, and to create social, economic and political institutions which will ensure justice and fullness of life to every man and woman.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We have hard work ahead.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: There is no resting for any one of us till we redeem our pledge in full, till we make all the people of India what destiny intended them to be.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We are citizens of a great country on the verge of bold advance, and we have to live up to that high standard.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: All of us, to whatever religion we may belong, are equally the children of India with equal rights, privileges and obligations.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: We cannot encourage communalism or narrow-mindedness, for no nation can be great whose people are narrow in thought or in action.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: To the nations and peoples of the world we send greetings and pledge ourselves to cooperate with them in furthering peace, freedom and democracy.

Title: A tryst with destiny
Sentence: And to India, our much-loved motherland, the ancient, the eternal and the ever-new, we pay our reverent homage and we bind ourselves afresh to her service.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Home Speech Nehru's Speech while moving the Objective Resolution By Jawaharlal Nehru Mr.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Chairman, this Constituent Assembly has not been in session for some days.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It has done much formal business, but more is yet to be done.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: We have been cutting our way and clearing the ground on which we intend to erect the edifice of a constitution.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It, however, seems proper that before we proceed further we should clearly understand where we are going and what we intend building.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It is apparent that on such occasions details are unnecessary.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: In building, you will, no doubt, use each brick after mature consideration.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Usually, when one desires to construct a building, one must have a plan for the structure that one wishes to erect and then collect the material required.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: For a long time we have been, having various plans for a free India in our minds , but now, when we are beginning the actual work, I hope, you will be at one with me when I say, that we should present a clear picture of this plan to ourselves, to the people of India and to the world at large.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: The Resolution that I am placing before you defines our aims, describes an outline of the plan and points the way which we are going to tread.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: You all know that this Constituent Assembly is not what many of us wished it to be.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It has come into being under particular conditions and the British Government has a hand in its birth.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: They have attached to it certain conditions.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: We accepted the State Paper, which may be called the foundation of this Assembly, after serious deliberations and we shall endeavour to work within its limits.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: But you must not ignore the source from which this Assembly derives its strength.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Governments do not come into being by State Papers.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Governments are, in fact the expression of the will of the people.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: We have met here today because of the strength of the people behind us and we shall go as far as the people not of any party or group but the people as a whole--shall wish us to go.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: We should, therefore, always keep in mind the passions that lie in the hearts of the masses of the Indian people and try to fulfil them.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: I am sorry there are so many absentees.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Many members who have a right to come and attend the meeting are not here today.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: This, in one sense, increases our responsibility.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: We shall have to be careful that we do nothing which may cause uneasiness in others or goes against any principle.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: We do hope that those who have abstained, will soon join us in our deliberations, since this Constitution can only go as far as the strength behind it can push it.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It has ever been and shall always be our ardent desire to see the people of India united together so that we may frame a constitution which will be acceptable to the masses of the Indian people.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It is, at the same time, manifest that when a great country starts to advance, no party or group can stop it.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: This House, although it has met in the absence of some of its members, will continue functioning and try to carry out its work at all costs.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: The Resolution that I am placing before you is in the nature of a pledge.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It has been drafted after mature deliberation and efforts have been made to avoid controversy.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: A great country is sure to have a lot of controversial issues; but we have tried to avoid controversy as much as possible.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: The Resolution deals with fundamentals which are commonly held and have been accepted by the people.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: I do not think this Resolution contains anything which was outside the limitations laid down by the British Cabinet or anything which may be disagreeable to any Indian, no matter to what party or group he belongs.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Unfortunately, our country is full of differences, but no one, except perhaps a few, would dispute the fundamentals which this Resolution lays down.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: The Resolution states that it is our firm and solemn resolve to have a sovereign Indian republic.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: We have not mentioned the word 'republic' till this time; but you will well understand that a free India can be nothing but a republic.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: On this occasion, when the representatives of the Indian States are not present, I desire to make it clear how this Resolution will affect the Indian States.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It has also been suggested, and the suggestion may take the form of an amendment laying down that since certain sections of the House are not present, the consideration of the Resolution may be postponed.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: In my opinion, such an amendment is not in keeping with the spirit of the times, because if we do not approve the first objective that we are placing before ourselves, before our country and before the world at large, our deliberations will become meaningless and lifeless, and the people will have no interest in our work.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Our intention regarding the States must be early understood.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: We do desire that all sections of India should willingly participate in the future Indian Union but in what way and with what sort of government rests with them.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: The Resolution does not go into these details.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It contains only the fundamentals.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It imposes nothing on the States against their will.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: The point to be considered is how they will join us and what sort of administration they will have.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: I do not wish to express my personal opinion on the matter.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Nevertheless I must say that no State can have an administration which goes against our fundamental principles or gives less freedom than obtaining in other parts of India.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: The Resolution does not concern itself with what form of government they will have or whether the present Rajas and Nawabs will continue or not.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: These things concern the people of the States.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: It is quite possible that the people may like to have their Rajas.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: The decision will rest with them.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: Our republic shall include the whole of India.

Title: The Objective Resolution
Sentence: If a part within it desires to have its own type of administration, it will be at liberty to have it.
